description: From Middle English tender, tendere, from Anglo-Norman tender, Old French tendre, from Latin tener, tenerum (“soft, delicate”).

entries.meaning: Sensitive or painful to the touch.
Easily bruised or injured; not firm or hard; delicate.
Physically weak; not able to endure hardship.
(of food) Soft and easily chewed.
examples: The Matrix is telling my brain this steak is tender, succulent, and juicy.

entries.meaning: Sensible to impression and pain; easily pained.
Fond, loving, gentle, or sweet.
examples: Suzanne was such a tender mother to her children.

entries.meaning: Young and inexperienced.
examples: The court later expressly adopted the tender years doctrine, which states that a child is incapable of contributory negligence if he is less than seven years old […] .

entries.meaning: Adapted to excite feeling or sympathy; expressive of the softer passions; pathetic.
examples: tender expressions; tender expostulations; a tender strain

entries.meaning: Apt to give pain; causing grief or pain; delicate.
(nautical) Heeling over too easily when under sail; said of a vessel.
(obsolete) Exciting kind concern; dear; precious.
(obsolete) Careful to keep inviolate, or not to injure; used with of.
examples: The civil authority should be tender of the honour of God and religion.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Care, kind concern, regard.
The inner flight muscle (pectoralis minor) of poultry.

description: From Middle English tender, tendur, tendir, tendre, from the adjective (see above).

adverbs.description: tender (comparative more tender, superlative most tender)

entries.meaning: tenderly
examples: Love me tender, love me sweet Never let me go

description: From Middle English tendren, from the adjective (see above).

verbs.description: tender (third-person singular simple present tenders, present participle tendering, simple past and past participle tendered)

entries.meaning: (now rare) To make tender or delicate; to weaken.
examples: To such as are wealthy, live plenteously, at ease, […] these viands are to be forborne, if they be inclined to, or suspect melancholy, as they tender their healths […].

entries.meaning: (archaic) To feel tenderly towards; to regard fondly or with consideration.

description: From tend +‎ -er. Compare attender (“one who attends”).

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Someone who tends or waits on someone.
(rail transport) A railroad car towed behind a steam engine to carry fuel and water.
examples: Half the coal was out of the tender, half the fire out of the box, half the trucks were off the track, so violent was the stopping.

entries.meaning: (nautical) A naval ship that functions as a mobile base for other ships.
(nautical) A smaller boat used for transportation between a large ship and the shore.

verbs.description: tender (third-person singular simple present tenders, present participle tendering, simple past and past participle tendered)

entries.meaning: To work on a tender.

description: From Middle English tendren, from Old French tendre (“stretch out”).

entries.meaning: Anything which is offered, proffered, put forth or bid with the expectation of a response, answer, or reply.
examples: Herein, the Bard plays with the word "tender" most liberally. The boldened instance of the word is that which pertains to the instant sense.

entries.meaning: A means of payment such as a check or cheque, cash or credit card.
examples: Your credit card has been declined so you need to provide some other tender such as cash.

entries.meaning: (law) A formal offer to buy or sell something.
examples: We will submit our tender to you within the week.

entries.meaning: Any offer or proposal made for acceptance.

verbs.description: tender (third-person singular simple present tenders, present participle tendering, simple past and past participle tendered)

entries.meaning: (formal) To offer, to give.
to offer a payment, as at sales or auctions.
